definition:
It is defined as follow $$K_n(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n):=
\left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
 1, & {\rm if~} n=0;\\
 x_1, & {\rm if~} n=1;\\
 x_1 K_{n-1}(x_2,\dots,x_n) + K_{n-2}(x_3,\dots,x_n), & {\rm if~} n>1.\\
\end{array}
\right.$$

It is easy to show, that $$K_n(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)=
\det
\left(
 \begin{array}{rrrrrr}
   x_n &  +1  &  0  & \dots &  0  &  0  \\
    -1  &x_{n-1}&  +1  & \dots &  0  &  0  \\
    0  &  -1  &  x_{n-2}  & \ddots &  0  &  0  \\

   \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots \\

    0  &  0  &  0  & \dots &  x_2  &  +1  \\
    0  &  0  &  0  & \dots &  -1  &  x_1  \\
 \end{array}
\right).$$

References: Knuth D.E. [**"The Art of Computer Programming, Volume 2:
Seminumerical Algorithms**]{}.
